mistaking an accidental for a normal opening of some of the cells,
he should have ventured to figure an eight-armed polype as
issuing forth from on of them, - a phenomenon which, I do not
hesitate to say, is entirely irreconciliable with our existin knowledge
of the organisation of the animal of which disks are the
skeletons.

5. The earlier publications of M D'Orbigny on the subject of
the Foraminifera, do not include any notice of this genus; and
neither in the systematic arrangement which he put forth in his
article in the Dict. Univ d'Hist Nat: tom V (1844), nor in that
contained in his Foram Foss. de Vienne (1846), is the order
<u>Cyclostegues</u> recognised, which makes its appearance for the
first time in his <u>Cours Eléméntaire de Paleontologie</u>, Tom ii (1852),
between the Monostègues and the Helicostègues, with the following
definition (p. 192):-"Animal composé de segments nombreux places,
en lignes circulaires. Coquille discoidales composée de loges, concentriques,
simplesou multiples; point de spirale." Under this order are ranged
the genera <u>Cyclolina</u> (D'Orb., 1839), <u>Orbitolites</u> (Lamarck, 1801
and <u>Marginopora</u> Quoy & Gaimard, 1836) <u>Orbitolina</u> (D'Orb., 1847)
